conclusion: To find the electromotive force (EMF) induced in the coil, we need to consider the magnetic flux through the coil and the induced current.
The magnetic flux is given by the product of the magnetic induction and the area enclosed by the coil.
The induced current is proportional to the change in magnetic flux.
The coil is square-shaped with side length \( a \), and half of it is in a uniform magnetic field that changes from \( B \) to \( 2B \) over a time interval \( \Delta t \).
The magnetic flux through the coil is given by the integral of the magnetic induction over the area enclosed by the coil.
The area enclosed by the coil is a square with side length \( a \).
The magnetic induction is uniform and changes from \( B \) to \( 2B \) over a time interval \( \Delta t \).
The change in magnetic flux is given by the difference between the magnetic flux at the end of the time interval and the magnetic flux at the beginning of the time interval.
The magnetic flux at the end of the time interval is \( 2B \times a \), and the magnetic flux at the beginning of the time interval is \( B \times a \).
The induced current is proportional to the change in magnetic flux.
The induced current \( I \) is given by the formula \( I = \frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta t} \), where \( \Delta \Phi \) is the change in magnetic flux and \( \Delta t \) is the time interval.
Substituting the values from steps 2 and 3, we get \( I = \frac{2B \times a - B \times a}{\Delta t} \).
Simplifying the expression, \( I = \frac{B \times a}{\Delta t} \).
The electromotive force (EMF) induced in the coil is \( \boxed{\frac{B \times a}{\Delta t}} \).
